metadata.name: LandWaves #69
metadata.description:
Reaction diffusion systems are mathematical representations of the behaviours of fluids that can be found in nature. A key characteristic of these systems is that the initial parameters are simple but the resulting process can be extremely complex. In LandWaves, pixel colours affect each other, line by line, from top to bottom. Frequencies of multiple oscillating sound waves are turning the brightness values of these pixels into sonic materia. 

This piece started as an experimentation in gallery spaces, then transformed over several different digital ecosystems, questioning their hyper-capitalist nature and mediated affordance.

Touch to listen

metadata.name: Crosswalk Monsoon #321
metadata.description:
The story behind this collection is that there isn't really a story behind this collection. It is the result of play, tinkering, and curiosity.

One of the beautiful things about generative art is how we can achieve drastically different results simply by modifying a few parameters or lines of code. As my first release here on fxhash was 'Sabler', it felt fitting that my release for #fxhashturnsone would itself be a modified version of that 'Sabler' algorithm, albeit giving drastically different results.

It is notable for the fact that this is perhaps my most 'chaotic' collection yet, letting go of carefully considered proportions, angles and positioning and here leaving that in the hands of the computer. In a way, this simple act represents several design decisions I never would have imagined myself making a year ago, highlighting my growth as a generative artist over the past year.

It is also a reflection of the inspiration gained from many of the artists and boundary-pushers in the space that each time unlock and encourage creations beyond the immediate comfort zone. For that, this is a 'Thank You' to all of you.

With that, here's to many more years of generative beauty and inspiration on fxhash and beyond.

As with previous collections, I highly recommend viewing the images at full size and savouring the details and the chaos up close. Pressing 'S' will save a 6000 x 6000 px PNG file.

50% of primary sales will be donated to the Processing Foundation.

metadata.name: Ichigo #468
metadata.description:
This generator is named 'Ichigo' (Ëã∫/ „ÅÑ„Å°„Åî), the Japanese word for 'strawberry'. 

Seeing each iteration from a suitable distance, small dots (to me, reminiscent of strawberry seeds) overlay different sequences of geometric repetitions, implying a sense of texture, grittiness and irregularity. 

By looking closer however, it becomes apparent to the viewer that the majority of the composition is in fact government by orderly elements, in this case grids of dots. 

This discovery invites the viewer to consider the output in front of them at different levels, near and far. At what point do you feel the dots begin to dissolve into a texture? When do you stop noticing the dots and instead begin to perceive the overall composition?

These questions are posed in a similar fashion as with meditation; at what point does something become something else? When does an in-breath become an out-breath and vice versa? 

Contemplation on simple questions like these can open a small portal into stillness and mindfulness by taking time to slowly observe our responses. 

23 palettes are included, each named after different areas of Tokyo. 

Press 'S' to download a full size 6000px x 6000px PNG output. 

As always, much gratitude and enjoy your piece.

metadata.name: Root #109
metadata.description:
Root, by Matthew Plummer-Fernandez (2022). A pseudo-simulation of plant intelligence and root systems. Each root apex splinters into more apexes that follow similar trajectories in swarm-like patterns. To illustrate a basic response to their surroundings, each root system is confined to an invisible container that the root tips appear to either inspect or repel from, framing the final state. The system is sensitive to the space containing it, so it may grow in another way on different screen sizes. 

Inspired by The Revolutionary Genius of Plants: A New Understanding of Plant Intelligence and Behavior, by scientist and author Stefano Mancuso.

Press 's' key in live mode to save a png.

The code that generates this work also contains an essay titled 'Root: hashing out the concept of regenerative art'

Press the '/' key (a symbol used for the 'root' directory) in live mode to save the essay as a txt file (best viewed copy/pasted into a word processor).

metadata.name: System Œ≤ #222
metadata.description:
Œ± -> Œ≤ is about "Increases in magnitude and decreases in computation". And still related the fleeting time in the generating process.

My role in this work is more of a discoverer than a creator. 

Try to reveal the possibilities of time perception in the generative art through negotiating with incomprehensible mathematical equations.

What I want to explore through this work is that behind the generated results, the dynamic process of generations are equally diverse and unpredictable.

When we watch the generating process displayed on the computer, changing instantly, moving, multiplying, disappearing, and we hesitate, wonder, pause, await, as if many possibilities of time perception have emerged in the fragmented moments.

_
press [1] -> Œ≤ 
press [2] -> Œ≤‚Å∞„ÄÄ 
press [3] -> Œ≤¬π
-
Press [s] in live view to save as PNG.
Press [d] in live view to save as hi-res PNG.
-
If you need your collection in SVG format, feel free to DM me.

metadata.name: Paper Mandala #280
metadata.description:
A collaboration with P1xelboy and Paper Buddha.
Beautiful paper mandalas made purely with code in Paper Buddha's style.
Features include:
27 different palettes
3 different mandala types (Lotus, Starburst Style 1 and Starburst Style 2)
Four sections of the mandala with one of 10 different pattern types (Dots, Checks, Crosses, Triangles, Stripes, Circles, Polygons, Lazers, Quadrants and Hatching)
4 different direction types of shadow - of varying length
Randomly placed star background
Randomly placed Nebula
Possible Special Pattern Effect with darker stippling pattern
Possible Nirvana Effect where random colors are added to one of either Golden, Silver, Bronze, Blue Moon or Sea Green palettes.

Using only code, this produces a unique output which does take a few seconds to load.
Press "S" to Save your unique Paper Mandala as a 2048 x 2048 JPG
Press "R" for a random shuffle effect - (please wait for reload) - Refresh page to reset

The project works in a responsive browser, so to set up for phone background or watch, resize the browser accordingly and Alt + Print Screen to get an appropriately sized image.

Offered as a Dutch Auction, holders of the first 20 tokens (1-20) will receive additional benefits in the form of utility for future releases in the P1xelboy/Paper Mandala collaboration series. (exact details to be determined)
This utility will remain attached to tokens 1-20 and transfer to the new owner upon subsequent secondary sales.

Uses p5.js and p5.pattern
@p1x3lboy @paperbuddha - September 2022

metadata.name: Artifact #479
metadata.description:
This project is about uncovering artifacts.

Each piece is determined by approximately 15 parameters. This allows for a multitude of possible forms, and each iteration is an artifact to be discovered within the multidimensional space.

This work is focused around discovery. It is about exploring the space of the algorithm, shedding light on its many forms, and sometimes finding artifacts of the real world embedded within them.

Technically, this work is a composition of three primary elements: Voronoi tessellations, orthographic projection, and the depth-sort algorithm.
The latter of these is integral to the rendering mechanism. It works intuitively, drawing distant objects before near objects, evaluating the distance of each object according to its geometric center. It does this precisely, and in doing so, it can produce interesting visual artifacts, drawing some shapes in an unexpected order.



This has been a fascinating study, bringing light to unreal shapes and forms, and uncovering artifacts in an impossible space.

I hope you enjoy it,
Nat Sarkissian





Technical Notes:
- Append ‚Äú&mag=N‚Äù to the end of the URL in live mode to specify a resolution multiplier. It will render the image N times larger than the size of your window. If you have specified anything greater than 1, a download will start automatically once the rendering is done.

metadata.name: Reading a book #742
metadata.description:
The formal structure of a book is beautiful by itself, but its aesthetic is the tacit atmosphere within which events take place in a story.

The WebGL real-time animation sets up an initial grid based on the fxhash. The grid cells get subdivided into another grid and the resulting cells become filled with pixels in color (~33%) or black and white (~66%).
The colored pixels come in 3 different coloring styles.
- Big Palette (~49%)
- Small Palette (~49%)
- Monochrome [b/w] (~2%)
4 noise algorithms modify the pixels of selected grid cells while at the same time 4 reset algorithms reassemble the initial image. The selected cells switch over time.

metadata.name: Richter #48
metadata.description:
Richter is the second collaboration of Richard Nadler and Leander Herzog, following their first project called Gerhard. A generative animation based on multiple layers of color and data, mixed, moved and painted over in realtime. Some fragments stick to the canvas while others get discarded to leave the existing layers visible, allowing a complex surface to emerge and build up over time.
 
Richter works with data from 4 of 24 highres images, 30mb in total. This is the maximum size fxhash allows for a project and three times more than Gerhard. Richard Nadler created stunning new textures, enabling more variation in composition and detail to emerge at much higher resolution. Leander Herzog created the code for the interplay between the layers, motion and interactions. Richter elevates the approach from Gerhard with new methods for the realtime rendering process and new features like offline-first caching. Both artists use different tools and are not aware of the details of each others process, meeting through the interface of pixels as data.
 
Richter is featured in the exhibition "Generative Abstraction" at Expanded.art in Berlin.
 
- Click to start a new layer of motion and color.
- Doubleclick to enter fullscreen.
- Press ‚Äús‚Äù to save the canvas.
- Append ?dpr=4 to the url to increase the resolution.

leanderherzog.ch/2023/richter/
leanderherzog.ch/2022/gerhard/
fxhash.xyz/generative/17030/

metadata.name: untelling the story #27
metadata.description:
narrative is a debased art form, an error
divorced from the central fact of reality
everything that can happen, happens all at once
the multiverse is trapped in static simultaneity

right click to save a version of your token suitable for printing A4 size, at 300dpi

metadata.name: Ignorance is Bliss #25
metadata.description:
"Ignorance is Bliss" is the second collection released as a part of NeoMent's "Abandoned Reality" series.

People often argue over things that are not under their control. But why bother? At the end of the day, your opinion won't change anything unless you have the power to accomplish that change. Of course you can say that you are aguing for "The Truth" or "Justice", but what's the point in your bickering if you aren't going to accomplish anything?
But you can go even further than that, you can choose to ignore global problems completely, live in your own world. One who doesn't know of a problem shan't worry about it - thus, ignorance is bliss. 
Is it right or is it wrong? What's the point in arguing over what I wrote if you won't change anything? All you can do is decide for yourself.
